segments.text: This is Deborah Beale, and I am interviewing Dr. Richard Thomas on the history of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
The date is June 15th, 1984.
Factory section on here already, so tell us who you are, but I'd like to put some background on the history of education and how it came down here.
Well, let me say how far back in it you talked about the university education principle.
I did all my work up at Ohio State and left there in 1964 and came to Texas A&M at that time.
My background is basically aerospace engineering.
That's the area in which my Ph.D. is.
also studied mathematics and math, too.
But I was brought into the Department of Aerospace Engineering here back in 1964.
You were gone for a few years, right?
You went to Maryland?
Yeah, yeah.
I made the mistake of leaving Texas A&M at one time, and I was offered a job as a department head at Maryland, and left and went up there.
My family and I discovered that some hard-bitten old Midwestern conservatives didn't fit well into the heartland of the liberal Eastern establishment.
And it was really principally Washington.
It wasn't the University of Maryland.
I enjoyed the university and had a great time there, but it was just the
of the general mood and environment of Washington, D.C. itself that we didn't fit into.
And so after we were there a couple of years, I determined that I had made a mistake in taking the family there and decided to go elsewhere and actually was pursuing some jobs in some other areas.
I thought, well, I would contact Fred Benson, who was deemed here.
And he was kind enough to offer me an opportunity to come back to Texas A&M.
And so we did come back then in the early 70s.
That was a right move, incidentally.
When you first came here, what type of research was going on?
Well, that's a very, very relevant question regarding the history and the impact of TEAS because within the Aero Department there wasn't any research going on.
And, of course, Mr. Rutter was our president then, and he recognized that
that research was key to the image of an institution that aspired to greatness.

I think if we take a look at any of the so-called great universities, particularly technological universities like MIT or Stanford or Caltech or any of those, their reputation is built more on their research than on their academic programs.
In my view, the undergraduate programs at MIT, for example, are rather pedestrian.
And I just assumed if I had a student who wanted to study, a son who wanted to study aerospace engineering, I'd just, frankly, I'd rather have him here than at MIT.
But when you get into graduate work, that's something else again.
It's a different story.
But it is research that makes the image of an institution.
And I once heard that Mr. Rutter had said, I don't know whether it's true or not, that he was going to make Texas A&M the MIT of the Southwest.
Or I guess that would also mean possibly make MIT the Texas A&M of the Northeast or something, although they'd have to go a bit to do that.
But it was clear that when I was hired here in 64,
They didn't ask whether I could teach or not.
They were interested in the fact that I had been involved in a very active research program at Ohio State.
And above all, I knew how to hustle money.
I knew how to go out and convince sponsors that they ought to give me money for research.
And there wasn't any, it was very clear,
that when I was brought in, that's what I was supposed to do.
Because, as I say, when I came into the Air Department, as I recall, there was not penny one of sponsored research work underway in that department at that time.
Now, they had had some off and on.
But there wasn't any large, consistent program.
You've been mostly aeronautical research versus aerospace, too.
Well, it wasn't even... No, I don't make any distinction there.
Oh, okay.
Yeah.
Now, shortly after I came here, there was another group.
within Arrow and coupled with M.E.
that had a piece of research dealing with propeller thrust studies.
And I'm sure they would have gotten that had I not been there.
But the

directive that was given to me was to go bring money and but did it change much between the time it came and seven no no no i don't think it i don't think it had changed much and uh and moreover i don't think that uh
I don't think it's changed all that much today.
Now the structure has changed a bit between what it was, what it is now, and what it was then.
And this gets into some of the personnel changes that have occurred between, since 64 and now.
I cannot overemphasize the importance of teas in that whole process.
And as a matter of fact, the importance of teas in my decision to come to Texas A&M.
And if you want to get into that now, we can.
But it was an absolutely critical thing.
Because quite frankly, I think if
If there hadn't been teas, I wouldn't have come to Texas A&M.
It's that simple.
And I well remember what a very positive reaction that I had after my interview here, because I thought, these people know how it's done.
And the positive reaction

came largely from two men, Al Kronk, who was then the head of the Aerospace Department, and above all, Harry Whitmore, who had just come in, I think, in, what, 63, I think, just a year before, to head up the Space Technology Division, so-called.
Now, I'm going to make some comments here that would appear to be critical of Al Kronk, but they should not be interpreted that way.
He was and still is, although he's in poor health now, a hell of a guy.
And I really came to love that man.
However, Al was like so many of our engineering department heads back in those days in that he was not research-oriented.
He did not promote research.
He did not push faculty to do research.
Texas A&M's image back in the 50s, I think, although I was not here, but I think it was one of a super undergraduate educational institution.
And in the engineering,
It turned out people that were very well equipped to go into industry and do the job.
But as I say, when Mr. Rutter came aboard in 1958, I guess, as Chancellor, I think, or President, I'm not really sure how that all happened, but he was the one who really started to promote
research activities at Texas A&M.

Well, we had, as I say, we had a number of engineering department heads, Cliff Semang in mechanical engineering, Bob Whiting in petroleum engineering, and on and on, Art Burgess in industrial engineering.
Great guys, super teachers, super educators, but researchers, no.

and quite honestly it was always my perception nobody ever told me this but it was always my perception that the space technology division and mr whitmore were set up to well one might say to go around al crumb
in the matter of research.
And I suppose that wouldn't be too far off base.
But really, it was more to supplement what Professor Crump was doing in the educational arena and get a very definite research thrust going.
And it was clear to me when I came down here in the spring of 64
that TEAS had money to spend in the promotion of research.
And above all, they knew what that meant.
And this had just a tremendous impact on me.
Because I had determined, although I looked at industry initially when I decided to leave Ohio State,
I had determined I was going to stay in the academic ranks.
And I went over, well, among the institutions that I interviewed was Georgia Tech.
And they had a pretty good research program.
But I was absolutely turned off by their attitude.
They wanted me to promote research.
They wanted me to hustle money.
And I said to them,
well, do you have money to travel, you know, to go visit research funds?
And they said, well, you can take that out of your research money.
I said, wait a minute.
You can't, you know, you're asking me to pull myself up by my bootstraps.
You've got to prime the pump a bit here, you know.
And it was clear they weren't all that willing to do that.
But Mr. Whitmore and Tease were willing.
And he understood.
And keep in mind, of course, an awful lot of that credit goes to Fred Benson, because he understands, too, what is involved in building a program.
And it's something that you just don't do overnight.
So they understood that in the promotion of research,
One does not sit down and write out a proposal, however technically excellent it might be, and send it to the sponsor, the potential sponsor, and say, send money by return made.
It just does not happen that way.
You must go there.
You must sell yourself.
You have to hustle.
And that, to some, is sort of the senior side of academia.
But you've got to do it, and there's just no substitute for having support of that type.
And I think that having the Research Foundation, of course, was a great asset, too, because there you could get a professional-looking proposal turned out.
Obviously, they, coupled with TEAS, would help you manage your research.
your project, your money, once you got it.

And that's essential because when I went, again, just to illustrate the counterpoint, when I went to the University of Maryland, again, I went into a department, if you can believe this, 20 minutes from downtown Washington, where many of the research sponsors were located.
And again, when I went to Maryland, that department had not paid anyone in research when I went there.
And they did not have an engineering experiment station.
They did not have a research foundation.
And I lucked out and rather quickly got a nice grant from NASA to do some wind tunnel studies.
And I had to hire a gal into the department office there to keep books on this project.
You know, the very sorts of things that the research foundation and MPs do for you.
Well, that kind of support, you see, is just of inestimable value in the promotion of research.
And so all of that infrastructure was here.
And, of course, Ohio State had had a very strong research foundation.
Their engineering experiment station was nothing like this one here.
So I had some appreciation of what these support institutions could do for you.
And that was all here, and that was all in place.
And to have that, you see, coupled with
With Mr. Whitmore's attitude, you know, yeah, I got some money for you.
And if you need help, you come see me.
And it was just too good to pass up.
And of course, I'd have to say that there were some other factors involved in coming to Texas A&M.
I was born and raised in small towns, and so I liked the kind of small town atmosphere.
And I liked the attitude of the people, and I thought it was a good place to raise my kids.
And so that, too, was a major concern.
But in terms of Dick Thomas's professional development, I don't think I could have found
And frankly, I tell young people today, I don't think they could find today any better atmosphere.
Although the teaching loans, of course, have increased substantially in recent years.
And that's, I know, a very negative factor in recruiting people.
But in terms of promoting research, it's difficult to find a better environment, a better atmosphere in which to do that.
So please...
He's contributed heavily, I think, to the elevation of Texas A&M's image as a research institution.
We've still got a ways to go.
But when you look, when you consider that, what, 25, 26 years since Mr. Rutter took over and set us on this path,
If you look back at what we've accomplished in those 25 years, it's really quite incredible.
It really is.
A lot of people don't appreciate that, but he's contributed heavily to that.
When you first came, was the wind tunnel still housing hay?
Was it still what?
Was it still a hay barn?
Well, not quite.
Almost.
That brings back a lot of memories.

The wind tunnel was there, and had recently, that is, I say recently, but I think, I'm not sure when it was, I think in the late 50s and early 60s, had been upgraded, because initially it was an open circuit, or an open throat type wind tunnel,
And you just have difficulty doing precise research in a facility like that.
And so they had closed it.
They had put in the return leg.
And Joe Bruce and his crew had just done a magnificent job of going in and ferreting out sources of turbulence and instability in the tunnel.
And they had put in the balance to measure forces on models.
But it had kind of fallen on hard times, because I think although they had put in the balance, they did not put in a data system, a system that would more or less automatically
process the data coming out of the balance and out of the one tunnel.
And I don't know whether that was, well, there was another problem, too.

I should back up here a bit and say, as you've probably already been told by others, that it was hoped that by upgrading the tunnel, that it could do, it could support itself with a lot of commercial testing for
people like LTD and General Dynamics and others.
And it also, of course, it would provide a basis for some good aerodynamic research.
Well, at about that time, for whatever reason, General Dynamics started building its own wind tunneling facilities, and other organizations did too.

And I think that, coupled with the fact that we weren't really equipped to do commercial processing of wind tunnel data, commercial testing, just led to the circumstance that occurred when I came in, and that was that the wind tunnel had been shut down, basically, and we're just sitting there gathering dust.
And so to that extent, it was a big one.
And I remember one of the first groups of students that I had, one of the first courses I taught that dealt with low-speed aerodynamics.
And so I went to Mr. Kronk and Mr. Whitmore, and I said, you know,
Can we use the wind tunnel for some student demonstrations?
And so I took a bunch of students out there, and down in the basement of the tunnel, we found a big box that looked rather like a coffin.
But in that box, we found a model, a wind tunnel model.
And it had been, it was a
Temco, that's the T in LTV, used to be Lintemco Walk.
And Temco, back, I don't know, back in the 50s, was preparing a bid on the development and production of a cargo airplane for the Air Force or something.
And they had this model.
And apparently they were unsuccessful in their bid.
And then, of course, were then absorbed by Ling and his operation.
And apparently never took the model back.
And so with the traditional Aggie enthusiasm, my students tore into that thing.
They assembled the model.
We installed it in the wind tunnel with Mr. Bruce's invaluable assistance, and we ran a series of tests on that model.
And again, this was just principally for the educational enlightenment of the students.
But we sort of blew the dust out of the tunnel at that time, and I guess it was through that experience that I...
I became convinced that it was a fine facility, excellent flow characteristics in it, again, due to Mr. Bruce's terrible work.
And I thought it was possible to do some research with it.
And although it was out of my area, I was trained principally in hypersonic aerodynamics and reentry processes.
I was not, and am not, a low-speed guy.
But I learned to fly during World War II, and I still enjoy flying.
And so, you know, to that extent, I'm interested in low-speed.
Because the airplanes I fly, they'll go very fast.
And I had done some crop testing and things like that.
We were fortunate then in the
in the mid-60s to get some work from NASA for work in the wind tunnel.
But here again, you see, I well remember a trip that I took to NASA Langley after having done what groundwork I could do by phone.
And I went up there and talked to a guy who eventually became a very good friend, Jerry Rainey.
and essentially convinced him that he ought to give some money to Texas A&M.
And you see, if I'd been at Georgia Tech, for example, or some other institution that didn't have that support for you, it would have just been impossible.
And there was another element to that incident
thinking back on it.
The aero department has a small wind tunnel, a two foot by three foot, I think it is.
Yeah, it seemed that.
That's not anywhere near the same wind tunnel.
Right.
However, we were doing some work on gust generators.
We were proposing for Langley to do some work on gust generations.
And we built a little prototype of our gust generator and put it
in that tunnel, in that small tunnel, to prove the concept.
And that construction of that little prototype was done with T's money.
And I'm sure that when I went to see Mr. Rainey at Langley, and I showed him, I said, you know, here we did a little very crude improvisation of what we wanted to do in the big tunnel.
And he was impressed with it.
And so here, this is just the way, just the way tea's, tea's work, you see, the tea's money works.
Just, just absolutely invaluable.
When you came back in, uh, 71, did you become involved in the shuttle research?
In what?
Shuttle research?
No, no.
What were you doing?
Uh, uh, when I, uh,
You see, in 1970, or well, 69, when Neil Armstrong set foot on the moon, the space program started downhill.
And also, for the first time in history, all three of the support areas generally active in aerospace engineering went downhill.
That is, aerospace engineering
in the 60s and so forth, 70s, rested on a three-legged stool.
One is commercial and general aviation.
Another one is military aviation, and the third is space.
And generally, in times past, those things would not be synchronized.
That is, if one went down, one of the other would be going up, and things were relatively balanced.
Well, in the late 60s and early 70s, for the first time in history, they all three went down together.
And it was not a good time for an aerospace engineer to be out looking for a job.
Research money had dried up.
The student enrollments went down in the early 70s because engineers couldn't get jobs.
It was a tough situation.
The department over here had more faculty than it needed.
And Dr. Norton and others will tell you, Jim Strickland, when he was alive and was here, they were urged to go out and hustle research money in order to keep themselves
afloat financially, because I think by 1973 or 4, I think the total number of graduates out of the department was something like 20.
And so when I came back, then Mr. Benson
put me in a position as a special assistant to him with the task of simply promoting some new research for the 14s and for the College of Engineering.
And I did not, as a matter of fact, my title at that time, my academic title was professor of engineering, not professor of aerospace engineering.
And so it was only
later on when the enrollments came back that I got involved again with the aero department.
And so, no, I had not anything to do with the shuttle test.
I think the only thing I could claim credit for was that prior to those tests we did get the wind tunnel back in operation and
And we had a going facility.
And then, of course, NASA came in and bought us a data system, bought us a computer to do the processing.
And that's the kind of a facility we should have had back in the early 60s.
Did they have those types of things developed in the early 60s?
Yeah.
Yeah, they were mostly analog computers.
We had one in Ohio State in the 1950s, and other facilities had them too.
They're nothing like, of course, you have today.
But yeah, they had facilities that made it possible to look at the data very quickly.
And that was the big problem.
You see, when a guy runs a wind tunnel test, he wants the results right now.
Because, of course, oftentimes he'll look at the data
And depending on the way that looks and his interpretation of that, that will determine what the next test is going to be.
Well, you see the setup they had in the late 50s and early 60s was such that they could take data in a very raw form.
And they had to bring it into the DPC, punch it into CARBs, and then process it.
And so, shoot, you were lucky if you got it the next day.
And, of course, those guys wanted to, you know, the sponsors wanted it right now.
And that was the problem.
When you came back as the assistant, were other departments besides aerospace having...
Were they what?
Were other departments having trouble getting research money, too?
Was there a slope in the others?
Oh, no, dear, I don't think I'd say that.
Incidentally, we're skipping over some other things here that occurred in the late 60s that would involve teas, and I guess we ought to come back and talk about those.
But because, you see, we haven't talked about the flight lab, we haven't talked about the shock tube, both of which were... resulted totally from what teas did.
But...
But to answer your question, no.
In the 60s and 70s, there was a general push toward the hiring of faculty that had research capabilities.
And so just as I had been hired into Arrow to promote a research program, they had attempted
and had been successful in hiring other people in other departments.
And so I think Texas A&M was moving ahead on a fairly broad front in research.
Now, these were mainly in what you might call the traditional areas of research.
And so when I came back,
I had a conversation, before I came back, I had a conversation with Mr. Benson, a conversation I will never forget, wherein he outlined for me what he thought he wanted me to do.
And incidentally, I was not an assistant dean at that point.
I was a special assistant to the dean.
And so it was purely a research endeavor.
It had no academic functions, and I didn't work with students at all.
But Mr. Benson, and of course it will be clear to you that I revere that man greatly.
A lot of people think that he's kind of a
a staid thinker, you know, who doesn't have much outreach, or looking for new ideas, and nothing could be further from the truth.
Because, and here again, this was
This was kind of a typical TEAS operation.
He just simply wanted me to find some new areas in which TEAS and the College of Engineering could work, non-traditional areas.
And as far as he was concerned, I had carte blanche to move in any direction I wanted to move.
It was as if he had given me a little chunk of money, which he did, and said, in effect, here, go do something great with this.
And it was absolutely one of the most exhilarating experiences I ever had in my life.
And he just ran some things by me, you know, the way he was thinking.
He said that...
He thought that, of course, keep in mind, we were in the midst of the Vietnam debacle at that time.
And he said, you know, for the first time in history, our technology has failed us in Vietnam.
Of course, we know now why that happened.
It was a political thing.
But he suggested
that we might do a piece of research looking at why technology failed, or if technology had failed in Vietnam, and if it had, why it had.
That blew my mind.
It, of course, would have been a tremendously interesting piece of research, and I nosed into it a little bit to find out that at that point there was so much stonewalling going on
And, of course, you'd have to get access to classified information.
And so we didn't pursue that very much.
He was very concerned about advanced transportation systems.
And that kind of surprised me because, of course, he had been the founder of TTI.
But he was concerned that TTI was not reaching out far enough.
And they were too content to sit here doing
highway research.
I mean, good stuff, don't misunderstand, good stuff, but research that was, again, pretty traditional stuff.

And at that time, you know, there was great interest in some of these people-mover systems and the old things like the Air Trans up at Dallas, the DFW airport, you know, unmanned, automated kinds of systems.
And he thought we ought to be getting into that.
And so we did mount some efforts in that direction.
The whole issue of productivity was beginning to emerge then.
And that later developed into a fairly substantial program for us,
to find ways to use new technology to increase the efficiency of manufacturing and production within the United States.
So still, of course, a very, very hot issue.
And I think it's a tribute to Mr. Benson that he saw that coming down the road.
So as I say, he just
wanted me to sort of follow my nose and try to develop some new research areas for the 14s and 45s.
So that was my assignment when I came back.
You said productivity developed into big studies, but here, what group was it that was doing this?
Well, there wasn't any group doing it at the time.
So the people that we drew on to develop that program were folks out of industrial engineering and I guess principally out of IT.
There were some other folks in ME and W that were interested, but the involvement principally came out of industrial engineering.
But the thrust of that
as it turned out, was, well, I guess there were two things.
One major thrust dealt with technology transfer.
Now, that has a different connotation today than it did then, those words.
Nowadays, when you say technology transfer, people are talking about the movement of technology from the U.S. to the Soviet Union.
which is an interesting and vital question.
But back in those days, it had to do with what might better be called the diffusion of technology.
That is to say, one of the things we studied dealt with numerically controlled machines.
These are machine tools, lathes, milling machines, and so forth, that early on were controlled
what you might call a very crude computer.
But it was a numerical system, an automated system, really based on punched paper tapes, paper tape with holes in it that contained signals that would guide the machine.
And so instead of having a machinist sit there with his eye twisting the knobs very carefully and so forth, it was all automated.
If you went up to General Dynamics, for example, and bought, and other aerospace manufacturers, for example, you'd find lots of NC machines.
You'd go to Hughes Tool, or Cameron Ironworks, or some of the smaller machine shops that populate Houston and Dallas, you'd find nothing, or very little.
Which indicated that, for some reason or other,
That technology had not diffused, had not moved through American industry.
And the belief was, quite properly, that if we could do that, if we could somehow stimulate that, that we could help industry increase its productivity.
become more efficient, become more competitive with Japan and Germany.
So that was the general move.
It headed much toward the manufacturing.
Was there a particular center or division established to handle this?
No, no.
It never evolved into that.
We just simply called it the Productivity Program.
And we had a problem emerge there, quite honestly, that we still have today.
And this is, I guess here I'm going, I'm about to utter my first critical remark of Teade's.
The kinds of work that I
was attempting to promote there, as I've already indicated, was interdisciplinary.
That is to say, we needed to get industrial, mechanical, and electrical engineers involved.
The reward system as it is set up now, and TEAS has been part of this, is one wherein a department head and a faculty member is credited, literally credited,
with the money he brings to his department.
And if a guy, let's suppose that a program is focused in some external center, in this center, for example, we still have this problem.
If I get a half million dollars to do a piece of research,
And I go to mechanical engineering and industrial engineering and any engineering department.
And I pull simply because the work is attractive.
I get, say, three professors, one from each one of those departments, to work with me on the project.
They didn't get any credit for that.

A portion, you know, although they would deserve, the department would deserve credit for a portion of that money that I've gotten because I got the money based on the capabilities that exist over there, you see.
But the way the reward structure is set up, it doesn't address that.
And so that's a real severe problem that, as I say, exists today.
And tease, and I've bitched at Dr. Porter and others about this, and they nod every time I complain, and say, oh, yes, well, here's Thomas and his usual gripe.
But it is a real severe problem.
So the productivity program
never really blossomed.
And the reason that it didn't blossom was that when I got some money, we got some money from the National Science Foundation.
Industrial Engineering took their little chunk of money and went back to Industrial Engineering and did their little thing and they said to hell with these other guys.
And I was just absolutely unable to
to bring any kind of an interdisciplinary effort there.
And so there's a real problem there that somehow, someway, we have to surmount.
And it's not an easy thing.
And Texas A&M and Tees is not the only one that has that problem.
It's a universal problem.
But the productivity...
